I was born in Australia but I lived in Canada for 2 years when I was younger. I love root beer but it is hard to find here unless you want to pay $2.50 a can versus 50c or less for a can of coke - they are imported A&W root beer cans. There is sarsparilla which is similar to root beer but it's not the same. I also like Dr Pepper which did come out here in Australia for a while but it wasn't popular enough to stay on the market (it's a cultural taste I guess) - that too is available now for around $2 to $2.50 a can for the imported Dr Pepper cans. With both of the imported Dr Pepper and rootbeer, the ones made in Mexico taste better than the ones made in the USA because the Mexican ones use cane sugar for sweetening while the US ones use high fructose corn syrup - I don't know if that is just a side effect of growing up consuming cane sugar over HFCS but it is what it is.

When I was a kid we used to get "spiders" which is actually different to a float (I was looking to see if I was right about red creaming soda being the traditional soda used here and found that out instead). A float has the scooped ice cream added to the soda (or the scooped icecream in the bottom of the cup with the soda poured on) while a spider has the icecream mashed with some flavouring syrup in a cup and then the soda poured over the top. We always had them made with red creaming soda but apparently people were also making them with lemonade like Sprite afaik, they could have also used lemonade similar to traditional lemonade but I can't find anything that matches what I am referring to that is sold in the USA beyond Rondo which left the market quite a while ago.

Chilled root beer and cold cups make less foam because gases are more soluble in colder water. There's more fizz still in the pop instead of it all bursting out when poured.

Oil trick: On Food and Cooking by Harold McGee notes that this works on the head of beer beer. Root beer often has extra foam stabilizers, and the ice cream stabilizes it further, so the oil does less.

Lecithin: Pre-dissolve it in a bit of water so you can get it properly mixed into the root beer. Not sure how it will affect the foam though.

With the warm vs child root beer it actually has more to do with the solubility of carbon dioxide at different temperatures. The colder the drink the less carbon dioxide is being released. That's why there is so much more foam with the warm root beer. It's because it's releasing more bubbles. Both the warm and the cold drinks (given the short space of time) will melt roughly equal amounts of ice cream. In fact the temperature difference is less important for this process vs the movement of the liquid over the ice cream, creating convection. This is why cold running water melts ice quicker than stagnant hot water. The emulsifiers and stabilisers in the ice cream are causing the bubbles to stay intact, causing the foam to be more stable.
